description: Why venvs matter, creating/activating them, installing packages, and pip freeze

cards.front: Why do you need virtual environments?
cards.back:
To isolate packages per project. Without them:

Project A needs requests 2.28
Project B needs requests 2.31
Installing one breaks the other!

With virtual environments, each project gets its own private set of packages.

cards.front: How do you create and activate a virtual environment?
cards.back:
python -m venv .venv   # create

# Activate:
# macOS/Linux: source .venv/bin/activate
# Windows CMD: .venv\Scripts\activate
# Windows PowerShell: .venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1
# Git Bash: source .venv/Scripts/activate

You will see (.venv) in your terminal prompt when active.

cards.front: How do you install packages and save dependencies?
cards.back:
pip install requests flask pytest  # install packages
pip freeze > requirements.txt     # save to file
pip install -r requirements.txt   # restore from file

requirements.txt locks exact versions so others get the same packages.

cards.front: What happens if you forget to activate the virtual environment?
cards.back:
You use the system Python instead of the project's Python.

pip install requests  # installs to system, not .venv!
python script.py      # might use wrong Python version!

Always check for (.venv) in your prompt.
Or check: which python (macOS/Linux) or where python (Windows).

NEVER. Add .venv/ to .gitignore.

.venv/ contains platform-specific binaries that do not work on other machines.

Instead, commit requirements.txt so others can recreate the environment:

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt

cards.front: How do you deactivate a virtual environment?
cards.back:
Simply type: deactivate

The (.venv) prefix disappears from your prompt.
You are back to using system Python.

You do not need to deactivate before closing the terminal.
Deactivate when switching between projects.

cards.front: What is the difference between pip and uv for virtual environments?
cards.back:
Traditional:
python -m venv .venv   # create
pip install X          # install
pip freeze             # list packages

Modern (uv):
uv venv                # create (faster)
uv pip install X       # install (10-100x faster)
uv pip freeze          # list packages

Same workflow, just replace commands. Both use .venv/.

cards.front: What is the standard name and location for a virtual environment?
cards.back:
.venv in the project root directory.

my_project/
    .venv/         # virtual environment (gitignored)
    requirements.txt
    main.py

The dot prefix makes it hidden on macOS/Linux.
Alternative name: venv (without the dot). Both work.
